awd_titl_txt: CEDAR: Characterizing the Polar Cap Topside Ionosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the polar cap topside ionosphere, a heretofore poorly characterized region of geospace, using novel experiments with the Resolute Bay Incoherent Scatter Radars (RISR-N and RISR-C) together with observations from the Enhanced Polar Outflow Probe (ePOP), observations from the three Swarm spacecraft, and numerical experiments using the Ionosphere/Polar Wind Model (IPWM). Although this project focuses on one region of geospace, it also relates to the connections between this region and other parts of the high-latitude geospace system. The polar cap topside ionosphere is a transition region with the magnetosphere through which ion upflows and outflows are transported. The polar cap is also a transition region between the dayside and the nightside, across which a significant amount of plasma is transported.
	A new pulse sequence will be developed for the incoherent scatter radars to enhance the sensitivity to the topside. The following specific questions will be addressed: (1) What are the typical properties of the polar cap topside ionosphere? (2) Which physical processes control the day-to-day, intraday, and patch-to-patch variability of the topside scale height and related quantities such as plasma temperature and ion upflow/downflow flux? (3) What do the polar cap topside observations imply about conditions upstream, e.g. in the cusp/cleft, and above in the polar wind?

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the properties of the polar cap topside ionosphere using a combination of novel radar experiments and physics-based numerical models. The ionosphere is the ionized portion of the Earth?s upper atmosphere, and it is created by extreme ultraviolet solar radiation and precipitating energetic particles (auroras) that ionize the atoms and molecules in the upper atmosphere. The topside of the ionosphere is the portion above the altitude where the ionospheric electron density peaks, which is typically around 300 km altitude. In the topside, the ion dynamics are primarily governed by transport processes rather than chemistry. The polar cap is the portion of the ionosphere closest to the magnetic north pole and poleward of the main auroral oval where most particle precipitation is observed. In the polar cap, the Earth?s magnetic field lines are open, meaning they connect directly to the interplanetary magnetic field (IMF) carried by the solar wind. The properties of the polar cap topside ionosphere are important to study since this region is the source of ions that will outflow along open field lines and populate the magnetosphere, a tenuous magnetic cavity surrounding Earth and beyond which the solar wind is mostly deflected.

A significant part of this project was devoted to conducting novel radar experiments using the Resolute Bay Incoherent Scatter Radar (RISR), which is a radar facility in Nunavut, Canada, near the magnetic north pole. The experiments were designed to use a variety of pulse lengths and a small number of different look directions to maximize the number of samples from each direction. During this project, we developed new radar data analysis codes based on the full-profile analysis concept in which the plasma parameters from all ranges are estimated at once, rather than one range at a time. Full-profile analysis can compensate for range-blurring effects from long pulses and incorporate a priori constraints on the smoothness of the profiles. Our full-profile analysis results in continuous and differentiable solutions, meaning we can also use the algorithm to estimate derivatives of the plasma parameters. The ability to estimate derivatives of plasma parameters means the code can estimate ion pressure gradients, parallel electric fields, electron heat flows, and a variety of other physical quantities important for understanding the structure of the topside ionosphere.

This project also employed physics-based ionospheric models to interpret observations from the radar experiments. In particular, we used the Ionosphere Polar Wind Model (IPWM), which is a model of ion transport in the polar ionosphere. We wanted to compare to data from specific events and therefore extended the IPWM to provide realistic inputs for energetic particle precipitation and convection electric fields. We used the Ovation Prime model for energetic particle precipitation, which is an empirical model derived from measurements with the Defense Meteorological Satellite Program satellites. For the convection electric fields, we explored using fields determined by the Super Dual-Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) as well as by the Active Magnetosphere and Planetary Electrodynamics Response Experiment (AMPERE). We performed detailed case studies of two particular events in which RISR topside experiments showed large ion heating and ion upflow in the topside ionosphere. In both of these events, the IPWM driven by either SuperDARN or AMPERE was not able to reproduce the observations. Closer examination revealed that RISR data showed much larger convection velocities than predicted by either SuperDARN or AMPERE, which suggests that global observations of convection electric fields are not adequately capturing mesoscale fast flows that effectively heat the ionosphere.

Both of our two case studies occurred under northward IMF conditions, so we performed a broader survey of the RISR database to determine how frequently those conditions occurred. This survey revealed that most ion heating events observed by RISR occur near magnetic noon during northward IMF. Northward IMF drives magnetic reconnection in the lobe of the magnetosphere, which generates localized fast flows in the dayside polar cap ionosphere.

This project supported a variety of early career scientists. Both the PI, Dr. Roger Varney, and one of the staff scientists at SRI, Dr. Leslie Lamarche, are early career scientists within 10 years of receiving their PhDs. Furthermore, this project supported summer research by an undergraduate student, Aaron Bunch, who assisted with the full-profile analysis code development. Mr. Bunch presented a poster at the Coupling Energetics and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions workshop in 2017 describing his work on full-profile analysis, and that poster won the award for best undergraduate poster.
